notes: Embodiment framed as regulation and attention training.

fine: Today we start with money safety: the feeling that you’re okay, regardless of numbers.
Your worth isn’t tied to your bank balance. We’ll practice that first.
One sentence to hold: “I’m safe enough to think clearly about money.”
stressed: If money stress is high today, we don’t solve it—we calm the system reacting to it.
You can care about money without letting it dominate your day.
One sentence to hold: “My nervous system comes first.”
tired_busy: We’ll keep this simple: no budgeting, no big decisions.
Just one small reset for your relationship with money.
One sentence to hold: “Money is a tool, not a threat.”
curious: Money safety is a skill: feeling secure even when finances feel uncertain.
It starts with regulation, not more information.
One sentence to hold: “Security is internal first.”

microAction.title: Money Pause
microAction.instruction: Look at one financial number (account balance, bill amount). Then say: “This is data, not danger.”

fine: Optional: notice if you avoid looking at money. That’s understandable—curiosity is the antidote.
stressed: Optional: if money thoughts spike, place a hand on your chest and breathe once.
tired_busy: Optional: postpone one money-related task by 10 minutes. Use the time to breathe.
curious: Optional: list one thing money does well for you. Focus on the positive data.

microAction.title: Positive Money Note
microAction.instruction: Write one sentence about what money enables in your life. Keep it factual.

fine: Tonight we release the day’s financial grip. You don’t need to control every variable.
Rest comes before results.
End with: “I can rest without financial permission.”
stressed: Your mind protects you by focusing on money threats. That’s evolution, not weakness.
Tonight, we let your body know it’s safe to soften.
End with: “I’m allowed to be secure without certainty.”
tired_busy: You showed up despite the busyness. That’s progress.
Money stress often hides in fatigue. Let it surface and release.
End with: “I release what I can’t control tonight.”
curious: Notice how money thoughts loop when you’re tired. Rest interrupts the loop.
That’s how safety builds.
End with: “Rest is my reset.”

reflection.prompt: Where did money feel like a threat today? What would ‘safety’ look like in one small way tomorrow?
exampleAnswers: Checking balances repeatedly. Tomorrow I’ll check once at a set time.
Avoiding bills. Tomorrow I’ll open one and breathe through it.
Worrying about spending. Tomorrow I’ll spend on one small supportive thing.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Today we separate money from emotion. Numbers are neutral data.
You can feel emotions about money without letting them drive decisions.
One sentence to hold: “Emotions are visitors; data is permanent.”
stressed: If money anxiety is loud, we don’t fight it. We acknowledge and redirect.
Your attention is your most valuable asset.
One sentence to hold: “I can feel this and still act wisely.”
tired_busy: Simple focus today: one money thought at a time.
No multitasking with finances.
One sentence to hold: “One thing at a time.”
curious: Money safety means your self-worth isn’t fluctuating with the market.
That stability is your real wealth.
One sentence to hold: “My value is constant.”

microAction.title: Emotion Label
microAction.instruction: Name the emotion you feel about one money situation. Just label it: “This is fear/anxiety/excitement.”

fine: Optional: choose one money emotion to observe today without judgment.
stressed: Optional: if emotions spike, step away from screens for 5 minutes.
tired_busy: Optional: delay responding to one money email by an hour.
curious: Optional: track how often money triggers emotion vs. neutral response.

microAction.title: 5-Minute Break
microAction.instruction: When money emotion arises, take 5 minutes to breathe before responding.

fine: Tonight we celebrate emotional distance from money. It’s not indifference—it’s wisdom.
You’re building better decision-making.
End with: “I trust my calm self.”
stressed: Even if emotions felt overwhelming, you’re still here. That’s resilience.
Emotions pass; habits remain.
End with: “I can weather this.”
tired_busy: Rest now. Emotional processing needs recovery time.
You did the work of noticing.
End with: “I release the day’s charge.”
curious: You’re learning to observe money emotions like weather: present but not controlling.
That’s freedom.
End with: “I observe without being controlled.”

reflection.prompt: What emotion showed up around money today? Did labeling it change anything?
exampleAnswers: Fear. Labeling made it feel less urgent.
Anxiety. I could step back and breathe.
Excitement. It felt motivating without panic.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Today we practice money trust: acting from steadiness, not reaction.
Your pace with money improves outcomes more than pressure does.
One sentence to hold: “Steady action beats frantic action.”
stressed: If you’re gripping finances today, that’s a sign you care. We soften the grip.
Care doesn’t require tension.
One sentence to hold: “I can care without clenching.”
tired_busy: Minimal money work today. Choose one small, supportive step.
That’s enough to keep momentum.
One sentence to hold: “Small steps build safety.”
curious: Money trust is earned through repetition: calm decisions, consistent action.
You’re training that today.
One sentence to hold: “Trust through action.”

microAction.title: One Supportive Step
microAction.instruction: Do one small money action that supports your goals (e.g., save $5, review one bill calmly).

fine: Optional: after your step, stop. Stopping builds trust in yourself.
stressed: Optional: if you can’t act, just plan. Planning counts as care.
tired_busy: Optional: make your step even smaller—2 minutes.
curious: Optional: notice how your mind wants to add more tasks. Decline them.

microAction.title: Stop After Step
microAction.instruction: Complete your micro-step, then say: “That’s enough for today.”

fine: Did you notice? Calm money action feels sustainable. That’s the point.
You’re building a new relationship with money.
End with: “I act from steadiness.”
stressed: Even if the step felt small, it’s progress. Tension doesn’t equal results.
You’re retraining your system.
End with: “I can try again calmly.”
tired_busy: Tiny actions are not small when they’re consistent.
Rest now—consistency needs recovery.
End with: “I’m human, and that’s okay.”
curious: You’re learning discipline: clean action, clean stop.
That’s how trust grows.
End with: “I choose clean money habits.”

reflection.prompt: What was your one supportive step today? Did tension try to add more?
exampleAnswers: I reviewed a bill calmly. Tension wanted more; I stopped.
I saved a small amount. That was enough.
I planned a payment. No extras needed.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Today we detach from money outcomes: focus on process, not results.
You can want financial goals without attaching your peace to them.
One sentence to hold: “Process over outcome.”
stressed: Detachment isn’t giving up—it’s giving your mind a break from constant monitoring.
You practice safety through action, not obsession.
One sentence to hold: “I can loosen attachment and stay safe.”
tired_busy: Gentle day: reduce mental money load.
Conserve energy for what matters.
One sentence to hold: “I don’t need to hold it all.”
curious: Detachment creates mental space. Space reveals better financial options.
Your clarity improves when attachment relaxes.
One sentence to hold: “Space improves decisions.”

microAction.title: Outcome Release
microAction.instruction: Name one financial outcome you’re attached to. Say: “I’ll do my part, and release the timing.”

fine: Optional: choose one money area to ‘not manage’ today. Let it be imperfect.
stressed: Optional: remove one reassurance ritual (e.g., checking prices repeatedly).
tired_busy: Optional: decline one extra financial task.
curious: Optional: observe what happens when you stop controlling one money variable.

microAction.title: Let One Go
microAction.instruction: Pick one minor money thing to leave as-is today. Practice non-interference.

fine: Notice how your body feels when you don’t manage every financial detail.
That relief is wisdom.
End with: “I can want more without attachment.”
stressed: If you struggled with detachment, that’s normal. Attachment is an old safety strategy.
We’re replacing it with steadiness.
End with: “I release one layer of attachment.”
tired_busy: You protected your energy today. That’s alignment.
Rest is part of progress.
End with: “I don’t have to control everything.”
curious: Detachment creates space for insight. Insight improves outcomes.
Let tomorrow bring clearer thinking.
End with: “Space brings clarity.”

reflection.prompt: What did you release attachment to today? Did anything improve—or did you just breathe easier?
exampleAnswers: A specific amount. I felt lighter.
Investment timing. Decisions felt cleaner.
Spending control. I enjoyed a purchase more.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Today we build money security: the internal feeling that you’ll be okay financially.
This isn’t optimism—it’s regulation.
One sentence to hold: “I can handle financial uncertainty.”
stressed: Your mind wants financial guarantees. We give it something better: resilience.
You don’t need certainty to be secure.
One sentence to hold: “I can meet uncertainty without collapsing.”
tired_busy: Simple security today: reduce the load.
You can progress without carrying it all.
One sentence to hold: “I’m supported in this.”
curious: Inner financial security prevents emotional spending/bargaining.
You act cleaner when you feel secure.
One sentence to hold: “Security improves strategy.”

microAction.title: Security Statement
microAction.instruction: Complete: “Even if finances stay uncertain, I will still ______.” Choose one truth.

fine: Optional: do one supportive act for your future financial self.
stressed: Optional: reduce stimulation for 15 minutes—no financial news.
tired_busy: Optional: choose rest over financial worry.
curious: Optional: replace one certainty-check with a supportive act.

microAction.title: Future Support
microAction.instruction: Do one small act that supports your financial future (under 5 minutes).

fine: Tonight we reinforce: you’re bigger than any financial situation.
That doesn’t reduce your goals—it stabilizes them.
End with: “I belong to myself first.”
stressed: Even one moment of financial steadiness matters.
You’re building a new default.
End with: “I can be with uncertainty and stay grounded.”
tired_busy: Rest is not avoidance—it’s recovery.
Let the day close softly.
End with: “I release what I can’t hold.”
curious: You’re practicing financial independence: calm before confirmation.
That’s real wealth.
End with: “I lead myself calmly.”

reflection.prompt: What security statement did you choose? Did it change how you felt about money?
exampleAnswers: I’ll still take care of myself. Felt more secure.
I’ll still have options. Worry decreased.
I’ll still be okay. Acted more freely.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Today we keep financial desire clean: no bargaining, no chasing returns.
Clean desire is calm, clear, and consistent.
One sentence to hold: “I want it, and I trust my pace.”
stressed: If you’re tempted to chase financial gains today, pause. Chasing is often fear in action.
We choose calm financial action instead.
One sentence to hold: “I act from steadiness, not fear.”
tired_busy: Minimal financial focus today. One steady decision.
That keeps momentum without pressure.
One sentence to hold: “Steady beats intense.”
curious: Clean financial desire removes emotional costs.
You think clearer when you stop bargaining with outcomes.
One sentence to hold: “No bargaining. Just alignment.”

microAction.title: No Bargain Statement
microAction.instruction: Say: “I’m not negotiating my worth with money. I’ll do my part and stay steady.”

fine: Optional: choose one aligned financial action without needing feedback.
stressed: Optional: pause one impulsive financial behavior.
tired_busy: Optional: one small financial act, then rest.
curious: Optional: notice the difference between aligned vs. chase actions.

microAction.title: Aligned Action
microAction.instruction: Do one financial action that supports your life regardless of immediate results.

fine: You’re learning emotional stability with financial ambition.
That’s how sustainable wealth happens.
End with: “I keep my center.”
stressed: If you chased today, no shame. Just notice and soften.
Tomorrow brings a clean start.
End with: “I return to steadiness.”
tired_busy: You did enough. Stop here.
Let your body recover.
End with: “I close gently.”
curious: Aligned actions feel quiet. Chasing feels sharp.
You’re choosing quiet financial power.
End with: “Quiet power wins.”

reflection.prompt: Where did bargaining or chasing show up financially today? What would ‘clean desire’ look like tomorrow?
exampleAnswers: Checking investments obsessively. Tomorrow: planned check.
Impulsive spending. Tomorrow: pause and reflect.
Seeking reassurance. Tomorrow: act aligned.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

fine: Day 7: you’re not ‘done’—you’re trained in money safety.
You can pursue financial goals without emergencies.
One sentence to hold: “I trust myself with money.”
stressed: If financial urgency remains, you now have tools.
Calm first is your new default.
One sentence to hold: “I can soothe myself and stay in motion.”
tired_busy: You made it through with simplicity. That’s the skill.
Keep it light today.
One sentence to hold: “I carry less, move better.”
curious: Integration: keep the mechanisms—reduce scanning, release attachment, act cleanly.
That’s reusable financial wisdom.
One sentence to hold: “Calm is my financial OS.”

microAction.title: Personal Money Reset
microAction.instruction: Choose one line from this week that felt true. Save it as your money reset.

fine: Optional: pick one financial boundary to keep (e.g., planned checking).
stressed: Optional: create a ‘when money spirals’ rule: breathe, name urgency, delay.
tired_busy: Optional: decide one daily financial support act.
curious: Optional: write your 3-step financial protocol: (1) name emotion (2) reduce scanning (3) one clean step.

microAction.title: One Boundary
microAction.instruction: Choose one financial boundary from the week to keep for the next 7 days.

fine: Close with credit: you practiced financial steadiness.
That supports every money decision ahead.
End with: “I move from calm now.”
stressed: Even if you struggled, awareness changes outcomes.
Repeat this anytime financial stress rises.
End with: “I’m learning, and that’s enough.”
tired_busy: Thank you for showing up realistically.
Finish softly.
End with: “I release the week and rest.”
curious: Financial results improve as urgency decreases.
That’s nervous system economics.
End with: “Less urgency, better outcomes.”

reflection.prompt: What changed most: scanning, attachment, or self-talk? Which program next?
exampleAnswers: Scanning reduced. Next: Wealth Identity.
Attachment softened. Next: Health Consistency.
Self-talk improved. Next: Love Readiness.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.

microAction.title: MICRO ACTION TITLE
microAction.instruction: One embodied, non-heroic action that trains regulation or attention.

fine: Optional extension that reinforces the mechanism.
stressed: Optional action that reduces nervous-system load.
tired_busy: Optional ultra-small version of the action.
curious: Optional observation or experiment.

microAction.title: OPTIONAL MICRO ACTION
microAction.instruction: Optional action that can be skipped without penalty.

fine: Reinforce progress without praise inflation.
Anchor calm consistency.
End with: "CLOSING SENTENCE."
stressed: Normalise difficulty.
Emphasise repetition over performance.
End with: "SOFT CLOSING."
tired_busy: Allow incompletion.
Encourage rest without guilt.
End with: "REST CLOSING."
curious: Reflect on the mechanism learned today.
Point out insight, not achievement.
End with: "INTEGRATION CLOSING."

reflection.prompt: One neutral reflection question tied to the mechanism.
exampleAnswers: Example response showing healthy processing.
Another grounded example.
A non-performative answer.

resumeCopy.neutral: Welcome back. We’ll continue from today—no catching up needed.
resumeCopy.warm: Good to have you here. We’ll pick up gently from today.
